qas.question: What does Darwin believe about the differences between species and varieties?
What does Darwin theorize about different species with regard to variety?

answers.text: "species are only strongly marked and permanent varieties"

qas.question: What did Darwin and Wallace make central to understanding the natural world?

answers.text: variation among individuals of the same species

qas.question: What did Darwin say that a "well marked variety" could be called?
What did historians say that naturalists generally thought about the differences in variations in a species?

answers.text: generally considered such variations to be limited and unimportant deviations from the archetype of each species

context: In Chapter II, Darwin specifies that the distinction between species and varieties <a0_0>is arbitrary<a0_0/>, with experts disagreeing and changing their decisions when new forms were found. He concludes that "a well-marked variety may be justly called an <a3_0>incipient species"<a3_0/> and that <a1_0>"species are only strongly marked and permanent varieties"<a1_0/>. He argues for the ubiquity of variation in nature. Historians have noted that naturalists had long been aware that the individuals of a species differed from one another, but had <a4_0>generally considered such variations to be limited and unimportant deviations from the archetype of each species<a4_0/>, that archetype being a fixed ideal in the mind of God. Darwin and Wallace made <a2_0>variation among individuals of the same species<a2_0/> central to understanding the natural world.
